<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
JOBS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/09/03/lowwage-workers-hurt-pandemic?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
The Pandemic: Not an Equal Opportunity Unemployer
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Closed theater" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yMzE5L2Nsb3NlZF90aGVhdGVyLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>William Campbell-Corbis via Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">It’s become a symbol of the pandemic: The hedge fund manager escapes to the Hamptons while the Manhattan line cook, their restaurant empty, gets laid off. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">That image reflects a consistent pattern in COVID-19’s impact on the labor market. Lockdown restrictions disproportionately affected <a href="https://www.brookings.edu/research/reopening-america-low-wage-workers-have-suffered-badly-from-covid-19-so-policymakers-should-focus-on-equity/#:~:text=Low%2Dwage%20workers%20in%20America,industries%2C%20took%20the%20hardest%20hits.?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">low-wage workers</a> in the U.S., the numbers show. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>39% of employed people in households making less than $40k were </span><span><a href="https://www.politico.com/news/2020/05/14/pandemic-job-losses-households-258710?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">furloughed</a></span><span> or lost their job in March, the Fed calculated. In households making more than $100k...just 13% did. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">What’s driving that trend? </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Before the pandemic, an increasing number of American workers were in the business of “feeding, pampering, and caring for other Americans, especially wealthy ones,” the WSJ’s Christopher Mims <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/covid-19-is-dividing-the-american-worker-11598068859?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">writes</a>. And it’s those same jobs—Uber drivers, building cleaning/security, hotel workers—that were most harmed by social distancing restrictions. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>When higher-income people stop traveling, going to offices, or eating out, it creates a disastrous ripple effect for the workers employed in those services.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>And there are a </span><span><em>lot </em></span><span>of people doing this kind of work. 9.2% of U.S. employment was in food preparation and serving occupations in May 2019, according to a recent </span><span><a href="https://www.hamiltonproject.org/assets/files/AutorReynolds_LO_FINAL.pdf?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">MIT paper</a></span><span> by David Autor and Elisabeth Reynolds. 8.5% work in transportation.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Compounding the issue is telework. It’s well documented that higher-paying “knowledge” workers are able to transition to WFH far more easily than lower-paying services employees, meaning it’s easier to preserve knowledge economy jobs. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Is any of this a good thing? </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">After all, eliminating low-paying, vulnerable jobs might theoretically be a positive development because it could push people into more stable employment situations. Autor and Reynolds argue that it’s not. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>For one, less demand for low-paying jobs does not mean a rise in demand for better-paying jobs that would employ the same people.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>There are also high costs associated with losing your job, forcing you to train and gain experience in another field.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>if the pandemic subsides and people start moving around again, lower-wage workers could return to the gains they’d been making pre-pandemic. But if growing trends like remote work and reduced business travel become permanent, it could shake up the labor market picture for decades.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-top: 12px;">

</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/09/03/snapshot-job-postings-pandemic?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Job Postings: A Snapshot
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>

<img alt="Indeed job postings " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yMzA2L2luZGVlZF9qb2JfcG9zdGluZ3MucG5nIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Indeed</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The trend in job postings through Aug. 28 is down 20.2% from 2019, according to <a href="https://www.hiringlab.org/2020/08/31/job-postings-through-august-28/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Indeed</a>. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">A quick dive into the numbers:</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>In hospitality & tourism and sports, job postings are stuck at least 40% below last year’s trend.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Banking & finance and software development are also down 30%+. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Job postings in retail, interestingly, have only dropped 4.5%, while construction and loading & stocking have seen gains over last year.</span></li>
</ul>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-top: 12px;">
<a href="https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2020%2F09%2F03%2Fsnapshot-job-postings-pandemic" target="_blank" rel="noopener" style="text-decoration: none;" class="">
<img alt="" style="display: inline-block; width: 25px" width="25" src="https://media.sailthru.com/5z8/1k4/4/2/5e865734bf6f7.jpg">
</a><span>  </span>

<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
GENDER
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/09/03/working-moms-invisible-labor-crisis?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Working Moms’ Invisible Labor Crisis
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Working moms" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yMzIyL3dvcmtpbmdfbW9tcy5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">This year, female unemployment hit <a href="https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/elections/2020/08/03/coronavirus-pandemic-sets-women-back-amid-unemployment-child-care-crisis/5573123002/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">double digits</a> for the first time since the Bureau of Labor Statistics started tracking it in 1948. And women are leaving the workforce at a <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/womens-careers-could-take-long-term-hit-from-coronavirus-pandemic-11594814403?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">slightly higher rate</a> than men, the WSJ writes.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">It’s a stark contrast to December of last year, when women accounted for more than half of the workforce for just the second time in history. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Supermoms can’t catch a break</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Not only are women more likely than men to work as professional childcare givers, they’re more likely to take on caregiving duties at home, too. And that's where most of us have been spending our time lately. According to a BCG study...</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>This spring, women were spending an average of 15 more hours on domestic labor than men were (65 vs. 50 hours). </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Pre-pandemic, it was 35 vs. 25. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">With many schools indefinitely going remote and childcare facilities re-hiring at a <a href="https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/how-the-pandemic-could-force-a-generation-of-mothers-out-of-the-workforce/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">slower rate</a> than other sectors, moms are staring down 80+ hour “work weeks.” And that’s for women who have the option of working from home.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>Experts worry this childcare crisis could widen the gender pay gap and stall wage growth for women. </p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-top: 12px;">

<img alt="" style="display: inline-block; width: 25px" width="25" src="https://media.sailthru.com/5z8/1k4/4/2/5e865734bf6f7.jpg">
</a><span>  </span>
<a href="https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=This+childcare+crisis+could+widen+the+gender+pay+gap+and+stall+wage+growth+for+women&url=https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/09/03/working-moms-invisible-labor-crisis&via=MorningBrew" target="_blank" rel="noopener" style="text-decoration: none;" class="">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SPONSORED BY GRAZE
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="#" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Let the Robots Do the Work
</font></a>
</h1>

<a href="https://www.grazemowing.com/morningbrew?utm_source=morningbrew&utm_medium=9_07&utm_campaign=dailybrew&utm_content=closeupdark" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Graze" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL3BsYWNlbWVudC9pbWFnZXMvMTUwNS8xNTk4OTE3NzYyLWNsb3NldXBkYXJrLnBuZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6ImNvbWV0LW1vcm5pbmdicmV3IiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em></em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">We don’t want to belabor the point, but Labor Day is our favorite day because we don’t have to do any labor. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">So there’s no better topic to discuss—<em>leisurely</em>—than <a href="https://www.grazemowing.com/morningbrew?utm_source=morningbrew&utm_medium=9_07&utm_campaign=dailybrew&utm_content=closeupdark" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Graze</a>, <strong style="color:#000">the world’s first fully autonomous commercial lawn mower</strong>. It’s the mower that’s doing it all, including disrupting the $100 billion landscaping industry.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">And now you can <a href="https://www.grazemowing.com/morningbrew?utm_source=morningbrew&utm_medium=9_07&utm_campaign=dailybrew&utm_content=closeupdark" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">invest in Graze with literally just a few clicks</a>. For our money, that’s the perfect amount of clicks for investing on such a chill holiday.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">We know you’re trying to take it easy, but forgive us for this one bit of urgent news:<strong style="color:#000"> the last day to invest in Graze is September 18th</strong>. So if you only choose one thing to do today, make it an investment in Graze.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><a href="https://www.grazemowing.com/morningbrew?utm_source=morningbrew&utm_medium=9_07&utm_campaign=dailybrew&utm_content=closeupdark" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Get all the info here</a>.</p>

<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
HIRING
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/09/03/pandemic-restrictions-force-managers-rework-hiring-practices?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Welcome Aboard! Hope to Meet You Someday.
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="Broad City gif" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=377 src="https://media.giphy.com/media/3ohhwIqvzoZI2O4o9O/giphy.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="Broad City gif" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/3ohhwIqvzoZI2O4o9O/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">It’s been a few days since your last interview and you’re getting nervous. Then, an email shows up from the hiring manager. It begins, “Congratulations! I’m very pleased to offer you…” You don’t read any further. You just got a new job! </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">If that’s happened to you in the <span style="text-decoration: line-through;">12 millennia</span> six months since pandemic restrictions began, the hiring process was probably a <em>little</em> different than usual. Social distancing has redefined recruiting as much as Justin Timberlake redefined the word “me.” </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">One example: The shift to WFH has allowed employers to broaden their potential talent pool exponentially. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>The remote model can open up a "new world of qualified applicants,” </span><span><a href="https://www.forbes.com/sites/forbeshumanresourcescouncil/2020/08/12/the-new-normal-of-recruitment/#68e808525173?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">writes</a></span><span> Marilyn Tyfting, CCO of TELUS International. </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The reverse is also true, Tyfting notes. “Candidates seeking work who previously overlooked firms that were unwilling or unable to accommodate remote work are now also throwing their proverbial hats in the ring.” </span></li>
</ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">But the internet is no silver bullet</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Just ask privacy or print media or your attention span. The <em>real</em> trick is learning how to onboard new hires in the pandemic era. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Introducing: The “culture buddy.”</strong> Employers such as SF personal finance firm Landed tried to help smooth the transition by <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/its-not-just-working-remotely-hiring-and-onboarding-go-virtual-too-11586963419?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">pairing up</a> new hires with a designated work friend, the WSJ reported. The reasoning: Company culture is perhaps the most startling aspect of a new job—and one of the hardest to absorb via Zoom. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">If nothing else, the great remote experiment has squeezed some valuable remote-hiring insights out of the circumstances, namely that you should overcommunicate and create a personalized onboarding plan for each employee.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>The shift to remote has <a href="https://hbr.org/2020/08/21-hr-jobs-of-the-future?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">underscored</a> the importance of HR—and what separates the good from the great in a people manager.</p>

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
PIVOTS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/09/04/new-jobs-continue-emerge-postcovid-world?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
It's So Crazy...It Just Might Work
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="Bert gif" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=469 src="https://media.giphy.com/media/LoGh1t5iGxFOE/giphy.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="Bert gif" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/LoGh1t5iGxFOE/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">When a pandemic closes one door, it opens several other, weirder doors. Here’s a quick rundown of the inventive ways people have made money during the coronavirus. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">The hustlers</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Pivot Services Lead:</strong> When the owner of a hostel chain in Thailand realized tourism was going the way of the dodo, he mobilized his resources and expertise to move into <a href="https://blog.appsumo.com/pandemic-side-hustles/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">adjacent industries</a>, including food delivery and visa services.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Chief Fortune Teller: </strong>A senior at Vassar College turned her <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/08/24/us/college-students-new-jobs-coronavirus.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">tarot-card reading hobby</a> into a full-fledged online business, using an Etsy shop to help customers schedule appointments and TikTok for marketing. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">The reimaginers</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">VP of Moving and Shaking:</strong> As strip clubs across the country closed, <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/10/style/justin-laboy-instagram-strip-clubs-live.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">dancers moved to Instagram Live</a> to earn money, pinning their Cash App handles on the top of the feed to solicit donations.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Head of Home Cooking:</strong> A new food law in California allows people to operate licensed restaurants from <a href="https://la.eater.com/2020/9/2/21418664/riverside-ab-626-home-restaurants-legal-california-chefs?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">inside their own homes</a>. No word on how dishwashing duties will be handled. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">The only-in-a-pandemic-ers </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Pro Tracers: </strong>Pre-COVID, there were roughly 2,200 contract tracers in the U.S. Now, public health experts estimate we need more than 100,000 to help track down people who may have been exposed to the virus. <a href="https://arstechnica.com/science/2020/05/i-enrolled-in-a-coronavirus-contact-tracing-academy/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Contact tracing academies</a> have emerged to meet the increased demand.  </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Farm Influencers:</strong> Faced with tough times, farmers have started <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/08/07/us/farmer-influencer-youtube.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">posting videos</a> of their daily lives to YouTube to supplement their income. Some popular titles from farmfluencer Morgan Gold: <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7SD3PvoPsF8&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>The Story of Margie the Murder Chicken</em></a>, <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=a4oB_n1L9TI&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>Puppy vs. Geese</em></a>, and our personal favorite, <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gwWKzq4WY3g&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>Our Freakishly Huge Duck (This Is Not NORMAL.)</em></a>. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"></p>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The art of the cold email: </strong>Brew writer Toby Howell got this job by sending a cold email to the cofounders, and he’s <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/07/15/not-suck-cold-emailing?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">sharing his secret sauce with you</a>. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">New opportunities: </strong>The remote work revolution was supposed to uncover new job opportunities for workers with disabilities. width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yMzE5L2Nsb3NlZF90aGVhdGVyLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eWilliam Campbell-Corbis via Getty Images\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIt’s become a symbol of the pandemic: The hedge fund manager escapes to the Hamptons while the Manhattan line cook, their restaurant empty, gets laid off. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThat image reflects a consistent pattern in COVID-19’s impact on the labor market. Lockdown restrictions disproportionately affected \u003ca href=\"https://www.brookings.edu/research/reopening-america-low-wage-workers-have-suffered-badly-from-covid-19-so-policymakers-should-focus-on-equity/#:~:text=Low%2Dwage%20workers%20in%20America,industries%2C%20took%20the%20hardest%20hits.?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003elow-wage workers\u003c/a\u003e in the U.S., the numbers show. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e39% of employed people in households making less than $40k were \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.politico.com/news/2020/05/14/pandemic-job-losses-households-258710?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003efurloughed\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e or lost their job in March, the Fed calculated. In households making more than $100k...just 13% did. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eWhat’s driving that trend? \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBefore the pandemic, an increasing number of American workers were in the business of “feeding, pampering, and caring for other Americans, especially wealthy ones,” the WSJ’s Christopher Mims \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/covid-19-is-dividing-the-american-worker-11598068859?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewrites\u003c/a\u003e. And it’s those same jobs—Uber drivers, building cleaning/security, hotel workers—that were most harmed by social distancing restrictions. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eWhen higher-income people stop traveling, going to offices, or eating out, it creates a disastrous ripple effect for the workers employed in those services.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eAnd there are a \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cem\u003elot \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eof people doing this kind of work. 9.2% of U.S. employment was in food preparation and serving occupations in May 2019, according to a recent \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.hamiltonproject.org/assets/files/AutorReynolds_LO_FINAL.pdf?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eMIT paper\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e by David Autor and Elisabeth Reynolds. 8.5% work in transportation.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eCompounding the issue is telework. It’s well documented that higher-paying “knowledge” workers are able to transition to WFH far more easily than lower-paying services employees, meaning it’s easier to preserve knowledge economy jobs. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eIs any of this a good thing? \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAfter all, eliminating low-paying, vulnerable jobs might theoretically be a positive development because it could push people into more stable employment situations. Autor and Reynolds argue that it’s not. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eFor one, less demand for low-paying jobs does not mean a rise in demand for better-paying jobs that would employ the same people.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThere are also high costs associated with losing your job, forcing you to train and gain experience in another field.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003eif the pandemic subsides and people start moving around again, lower-wage workers could return to the gains they’d been making pre-pandemic. But if growing trends like remote work and reduced business travel become permanent, it could shake up the labor market picture for decades.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThis year, female unemployment hit \u003ca href=\"https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/elections/2020/08/03/coronavirus-pandemic-sets-women-back-amid-unemployment-child-care-crisis/5573123002/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edouble digits\u003c/a\u003e for the first time since the Bureau of Labor Statistics started tracking it in 1948. And women are leaving the workforce at a \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/womens-careers-could-take-long-term-hit-from-coronavirus-pandemic-11594814403?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eslightly higher rate\u003c/a\u003e than men, the WSJ writes.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIt’s a stark contrast to December of last year, when women accounted for more than half of the workforce for just the second time in history. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eSupermoms can’t catch a break\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eNot only are women more likely than men to work as professional childcare givers, they’re more likely to take on caregiving duties at home, too. And that's where most of us have been spending our time lately. According to a BCG study...\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThis spring, women were spending an average of 15 more hours on domestic labor than men were (65 vs. 50 hours). \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003ePre-pandemic, it was 35 vs. 25. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWith many schools indefinitely going remote and childcare facilities re-hiring at a \u003ca href=\"https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/how-the-pandemic-could-force-a-generation-of-mothers-out-of-the-workforce/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eslower rate\u003c/a\u003e than other sectors, moms are staring down 80+ hour “work weeks.” And that’s for women who have the option of working from home.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eExperts Hope to Meet You Someday.\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c!--[if mso]\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Broad City gif\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" height=377 src=\"https://media.giphy.com/media/3ohhwIqvzoZI2O4o9O/giphy.gif\"\u003e\n\u003c![endif]--\u003e\n\u003c!--[if !mso]\u003e--\u003e\u003c!-- --\u003e\n\u003cimg class=\"story-header-image\" alt=\"Broad City gif\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" src=\"https://media.giphy.com/media/3ohhwIqvzoZI2O4o9O/giphy.gif\"\u003e\n\u003c!--\u003c![endif]--\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eGiphy\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIt’s been a few days since your last interview and you’re getting nervous. Then, an email shows up from the hiring manager. It begins, “Congratulations! I’m very pleased to offer you…” You don’t read any further. You just got a new job! \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIf that’s happened to you in the \u003cspan style=\"text-decoration: line-through;\"\u003e12 millennia\u003c/span\u003e six months since pandemic restrictions began, the hiring process was probably a \u003cem\u003elittle\u003c/em\u003e different than usual. Social distancing has redefined recruiting as much as Justin Timberlake redefined the word “me.” \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eOne example: The shift to WFH has allowed employers to broaden their potential talent pool exponentially. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eThe remote model can open up a \"new world of qualified applicants,” \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/forbeshumanresourcescouncil/2020/08/12/the-new-normal-of-recruitment/#68e808525173?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewrites\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e Marilyn Tyfting, CCO of TELUS International. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe reverse is also true, Tyfting notes. “Candidates seeking work who previously overlooked firms that were unwilling or unable to accommodate remote work are now also throwing their proverbial hats in the ring.” \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eBut the internet is no silver bullet\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eJust ask privacy or print media or your attention span. The \u003cem\u003ereal\u003c/em\u003e trick is learning how to onboard new hires in the pandemic era. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eIntroducing: The “culture buddy.”\u003c/strong\u003e Employers such as SF personal finance firm Landed tried to help smooth the transition by \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/its-not-just-working-remotely-hiring-and-onboarding-go-virtual-too-11586963419?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003epairing up\u003c/a\u003e new hires with a designated work friend, the WSJ reported. The reasoning: Company culture is perhaps the most startling aspect of a new job—and one of the hardest to absorb via Zoom. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIf nothing else, the great remote experiment has squeezed some valuable remote-hiring insights out of the circumstances, namely that you should overcommunicate and create a personalized onboarding plan for each employee.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eThe shift to remote has \u003ca href=\"https://hbr.org/2020/08/21-hr-jobs-of-the-future?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eunderscored\u003c/a\u003e the importance of HR—and what separates the good from the great in a people manager.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWhen a pandemic closes one door, it opens several other, weirder doors. Here’s a quick rundown of the inventive ways people have made money during the coronavirus. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eThe hustlers\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003ePivot Services Lead:\u003c/strong\u003e When the owner of a hostel chain in Thailand realized services.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eChief Fortune Teller: \u003c/strong\u003eA senior at Vassar College turned her \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/08/24/us/college-students-new-jobs-coronavirus.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etarot-card reading hobby\u003c/a\u003e into a full-fledged online business, using an Etsy shop to help customers schedule appointments and TikTok for marketing. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eThe reimaginers\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eVP of Moving and Shaking:\u003c/strong\u003e As strip clubs across the country closed, \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/10/style/justin-laboy-instagram-strip-clubs-live.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edancers moved to Instagram Live\u003c/a\u003e to earn money, pinning their Cash App handles on the top of the feed to solicit donations.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eHead of Home Cooking:\u003c/strong\u003e A new food law in California allows people to operate licensed restaurants from \u003ca href=\"https://la.eater.com/2020/9/2/21418664/riverside-ab-626-home-restaurants-legal-california-chefs?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003einside their own homes\u003c/a\u003e. No word on how dishwashing duties will be handled. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eThe only-in-a-pandemic-ers \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003ePro Tracers: \u003c/strong\u003ePre-COVID, there were roughly 2,200 contract tracers in the U.S. Now, public health experts estimate we need more than 100,000 to help track down people who may have been exposed to the virus. \u003ca href=\"https://arstechnica.com/science/2020/05/i-enrolled-in-a-coronavirus-contact-tracing-academy/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eContact tracing academies\u003c/a\u003e have emerged to meet the increased demand.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eFarm Influencers:\u003c/strong\u003e Faced with tough times, farmers have started \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/08/07/us/farmer-influencer-youtube.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eposting videos\u003c/a\u003e of their daily lives to YouTube to supplement their income. Some popular titles from farmfluencer Morgan Gold: \u003ca href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7SD3PvoPsF8\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eThe Story of Margie the Murder Chicken\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=a4oB_n1L9TI\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e\u003cem\u003ePuppy vs. Geese\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e, and our personal favorite, \u003ca href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gwWKzq4WY3g\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eOur Freakishly Huge Duck (This Is Not NORMAL.)\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-top: 12px;\"\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2020%2F09%2F04%2Fnew-jobs-continue-emerge-postcovid-world\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none;\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"\" style=\"display: inline-block;
